comments.body: The braces are unnecessary.
Fixed.

I think that when this function is called, there should _always_ be a value here, so crashing would be appropriate. If we haven't initialized the ledger, the code should be calling `lookupInitialLedgerEnd` instead.

What happens if you revert this? What breaks?

~Yes, that's correct, @SamirTalwar-DA.~
That's only correct, if we initialize the index DB with the "fake" offset. But since this PR avoids doing that, we need to return `Offset.begin`.

The previous behaviour was:
1. If called prior to ledger initialisation - _crash_
2. If called post initialisation but pre first ledger end update - _default to Offset.begin_
3. If called post first ledger end update - _return most recently updated ledger_end_

This change means that the default provided in #2 above comes from the method as opposed to from the database column.

As many things could be happening asynchronously during startup I think it is safest to leave the default, or leave it someone more expert in the area to remove it ;-)

comments.body:
A rejection entry can be added:
- By `JdbcIndexer`, when consuming a `ReadService` update
- By `SqlLedger`, when the time model check fails
- By `JdbcLedgerDao`, when persisting the transaction fails with a consistency error

comments.body:
Removing this means loading an already stored rejection will fall through to the catch all case and fail with a `sys.error`. I think we need to keep the `TimedOut` case.

The alternative is to write a simple migration that updates all rejection reasons from `TimedOut` to `InvalidLedgerTime`.

comments.body: Everything else cascades; why not this one?
Because I like dangling indexes. :smile: Good catch, thanks, I'll fix this.
Addressed by https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/pull/4681/commits/92dc224b1c0325df0b56d7b8c3579c79268d8cf3.
Looks like this `executionContext` comes from `actorSystem.dispatcher`, which comes from the `StandaloneIndexer`'s actor system. Just wanted to make sure we're OK with this.

I agree we should change this, but in the context of this object (as it is right now) the `executionContext` is where `Future`s should be ran. I'll probably have a go at this as part of my participant redesign story.

Thanks for pointing this out though, as mentioned I agree that we could do a better job at organizing our thread pools.

+                    deduplicationKey,

+                    originalTtl,
+                    Some(Right(()))))

+                Some(

+                    deduplicationKey,
+                    originalSubmittedAt,
+                    originalTtl,
+                    Some(Left(error))))
+              case data =>
+                sys.error(s"Invalid command deduplication row $data")
+            }
+        ),
+        _ => None
+      )
+    }
+

+      |where deduplication_key={deduplicationKey} and submitted_at={submittedAt}
+    """.stripMargin)

+      deduplicationKey: String,
+      submittedAt: Instant,
+      result: Either[String, Unit]): Future[Unit] =
+    dbDispatcher.executeSql("deduplicate_command") { implicit conn =>
